What does the standards say about config: Configurable values (values which may change later) should be extracted from code and placed in configuration files.
What must be done regarding third-party: Any third-party libraries (NuGet, npm, dlls, JS libraries, etc.) must be approved by the CTO before use.
What must be done regarding service inte: Interfaces for classes in a service must be added to the .Common project in that service.
Where should IReportManager.cs reside?: IReportManager.cs should be in Report.Common even though ReportManager.cs lives in Report.ClientService.
Where should Unit Test projects be locat: Unit Tests should live in the folder of the project they test and be named ProjectName.Tests.
What should never be done regarding prod: Production secrets (API keys, connection strings, etc.) must NEVER be committed to source control.
What does the standard say about config: Config files in source control should default to point to Cloud environments, not On-Prem.
What environment should .NET apps defaul: All .NET apps should be committed with DEV1 as the default environment configuration.
What environment configuration should be: DEV1 configuration should be uncommented in the config file by default.
What must be done regarding single-line: Single-line if statements must be wrapped in braces for readability and maintainability.
What is the rule for C# class naming?: Class names use PascalCase and should be nouns that describe the object’s role.
What is the naming convention for interf: Interfaces should not use an 'I' prefix unless adhering to .NET framework conventions.
What is the naming convention for privat: Private fields should use camelCase with a leading underscore, e.g., _userId.
What naming pattern should boolean-retur: Boolean methods should start with 'Is', 'Has', or 'Should'.
What should methods that perform actions: Action methods should begin with verbs like Get, Save, or Delete.
What is the standard for file naming in: Use kebab-case for filenames (e.g., machine-info.js, machine-info.css).
What is the rule about magic numbers?: Avoid magic numbers; use constants or enumerations instead.
What is the guideline for exception hand: Exceptions must be logged and handled appropriately, never silently ignored.
What is the rule about rethrowing except: If rethrowing an exception, use 'throw;' to preserve the original stack trace.
What must be done regarding logging?: Use structured logging and include relevant context information.
What is the rule about using SELECT * in: Avoid SELECT *; specify explicit columns for clarity and performance.
What is the standard for time zones?: Store and transmit all DateTime values in UTC.
How should UTC and local times be named?: Append 'Utc' or 'Local' to property names to indicate their kind.
What should be the default DateTimeKind: Always set DateTimeKind to Utc for persisted timestamps.
What should be avoided when building SQL: Avoid string concatenation; use parameterized queries instead.
What should be avoided regarding LINQ-to: Avoid calling non-translatable functions inside LINQ-to-Entities queries.
What must be done regarding migrations?: Database migrations must be reviewed and version-controlled.
What should unit tests return on failure: Tests must fail explicitly using Assert methods, not silent conditions.
What is the naming pattern for test proj: Test projects should follow the format ProjectName.Tests.
What is the naming pattern for test clas: Test class names should match the class under test with 'Tests' appended.
What does the standard say about console: Avoid using console.log in production; use a logging framework instead.
What should AJAX requests use for JSON b: Set contentType to application/json and serialize data with JSON.stringify().
What is the standard for handling long-r: Support cancellation tokens and terminate server work when the client aborts.
What is the guideline for configuration: Use environment-based config files (e.g., appsettings.Dev1.json, appsettings.Prod.json).
What is the rule for dependency injectio: All services should use dependency injection; avoid service locators.
What must be done for service registrati: Register interfaces and their implementations explicitly in the startup configuration.
What is the standard for comments?: Use comments to explain 'why' not 'what'—code should be self-explanatory.
What is the rule for method length?: Methods should be concise and fit within one screen (≈30 lines max).
What must be done regarding class respon: Each class should have a single, clear responsibility (SRP).
What should be done before committing co: Run all unit tests and static analysis; ensure zero warnings and code smells.
What should be avoided when naming folde: Avoid spaces and special characters in folder names.
What is the rule about null returns in c: Never return null collections; return an empty list or enumerable instead.
What is the standard for version control: Use feature branches and meaningful names (feature/add-new-report).
What is the guideline for commit message: Commit messages should be imperative and describe the change (e.g., 'Add new report filter').
What is the rule for application logging: Log exceptions at the source and include correlation IDs for tracing.
What should be avoided in log messages?: Avoid logging sensitive information such as user credentials or tokens.
What is the standard for error codes?: Use consistent error codes and messages across APIs.
What is the rule for CORS configuration?: Only allow trusted origins in CORS settings; never use '*'.
What should be used to store sensitive c: Store secrets in Azure Key Vault or secure environment variables.
What is the rule for pull requests?: All pull requests must have peer review and CI validation before merge.
What should be done when refactoring?: Ensure refactors do not change behavior and retain passing test coverage.
What must be done regarding coding style: Use .editorconfig and stylecop.json to enforce consistent code formatting.
What is the rule for method parameter co: Avoid methods with more than 5 parameters; use DTOs when needed.
What should be avoided in asynchronous m: Avoid using async void; return Task or Task<T> instead.
What is the rule for naming asynchronous: Append 'Async' to method names that use async/await.
